https://prez.dev/description.@value: The status of a borehole during which liquids or gas are being pumped into a reservoir. The purpose of this activity may be to enhance production of petroleum, provide for storage of petroleum, provide for storage of gas such as hydrogen, provide for storage/disposal of treated waste liquids or gas, such as carbon dioxide, recharge aquifers, tap geothermal energy, or assist environmental remediation for the clean-up of contaminated groundwater. Boreholes/wells are specifically designed/drilled for this purpose, although a production well can be converted into an injection well and vice versa.
The subject is an instance of a class.
The defininition of the subject resource.
An idea or notion; a unit of thought
An alternative lexical label for a resource
Relates a concept to a concept that is more general in meaning
A statement or formal explanation of the meaning of a concept

skos:exactMatch is used to link two concepts, indicating a high degree of confidence that the concepts can be used interchangeably across a wide range of information retrieval applications. skos:exactMatch is a transitive property, and is a sub-property of skos:closeMatch
A note about the past state/use/meaning of a concept
Relates a resource (for example a concept) to a concept scheme in which it is included
Relates a concept to a concept that is more specific in meaning
A notation, also known as classification code, is a string of characters such as 'T58.5' or '303.4833' used to uniquely identify a concept within the scope of a given concept scheme
The preferred lexical label for a resource, in a given language

The stage of a borehole in relation to the lifecycle of the borehole, from proposal and operational stages through to completion and rehabilitation, and with a focus on terminology as applied in the Geological Survey of Western Australia (GSWA) databases. The vocabulary focuses on standard terminology from the energy and mineral resources sectors, highlighting instances where the same term carries different meaning in different fields. In the context of this vocabulary, the term fluid energy refers to sources such as gas, petroleum and geothermal, as covered by the Petroleum Legislation Amendment Act 2024, and is exclusive of mineral sources of energy (e.g. coal, uranium). Note that the currency of borehole status data in GSWA's databases is time-stamped, reflecting information gathered from a borehole operator’s well completion report or from a responsible regulatory authority at a specific point in time; subsequent changes are unlikely to be recorded.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The status of a borehole during which fluids (commonly gas and water) are injected rather than produced, typically with the primary objective of maintaining/increasing reservoir pressure to enhance production. Injection wells are also used to dispose of treated wastewater, recharge aquifers, tap geothermal energy, and in environmental remediation for the cleanup of contaminated soil or groundwater; the concept includes injecting for permanent storage. Boreholes/wells are specifically designed/drilled for this purpose, although a production well can be converted into an injection well and vice versa.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#hist.@value: Derived from PPDM Wellbore Status vocabulary (2014).

https://prez.dev/description.@value: The status of a borehole during which fluids (commonly gas and water) are injected rather than produced, typically with the primary objective of maintaining/increasing reservoir pressure to enhance production. Injection wells are also used to dispose of treated wastewater, recharge aquifers, tap geothermal energy, and in environmental remediation for the cleanup of contaminated soil or groundwater; the concept includes injecting for permanent storage. Boreholes/wells are specifically designed/drilled for this purpose, although a production well can be converted into an injection well and vice versa.

A reservoir maintenance or secondary recovery method that uses injected gas to supplement the pressure in an oil reservoir or field. This concept includes injecting for the purpose of permanent gas storage (e.g. CO₂).

Waterflooding or water injection is where water is injected into the oil reservoir, to maintain the pressure (also known as voidage replacement) or to drive oil towards the wells, and thereby increase production. Water-injection wells are common offshore, where filtered and treated seawater is injected into a lower water-bearing section of the reservoir. The concept includes water recharge of aquifers.
The status of a borehole during which liquids or gas are being pumped into the borehole.
A profile for SKOS Concept Schemes
A citation or reference to another creative work, such as another publication, web page, scholarly article, etc
